intro: Aliciella haydenii subsp. crandallii, commonly known as the Crandall's alicia, is a rare and specialized plant species native to specific regions of the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its small, needle-like leaves and compact growth habit, adapted to thrive in arid and rocky environments. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically green or white, followed by distinctive, three-lobed seed pods. It is often found in association with other xerophytic species, growing in well-drained soils. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a sensitive indicator of ecological health in its native range.
